This estimation yields the following cooling rates for the various samples: 1 × 10 3 Ks −1 (ϕ2 mm), 1.1 × 10 2 Ks −1 (ϕ6 mm), 40 Ks −1 (ϕ10 mm), 10 Ks −1 (ϕ20 mm) and 1.6 Ks −1 (100 g ingot). It is known that the cooling rate usually has a strong influence on the volume fraction of the β-phase in Zr/Ti-based BMGCs and the volume fractions tend to increase with lowering the cooling rates 21 29. Because the cooling rate in the 100 g ingot is more than 20 times lower than in the case of the rod with a diameter of 10 mm, there is much more time for the precipitation of β-Ti. Consequently, the crystalline volume fraction should be much higher in the ingot than in the ϕ10 mm rod. Contrary to expectation, the volume fraction of β-Ti does not change when the cooling rate is between 40 and 1.6 K s −1 and only the dendrites become coarser ( Fig. 1h).
